reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I’ve spent my life buying simple businesses I understand—Coca-Cola, GEICO, See’s Candies—and Amazon’s mix of retail, logistics and cloud computing falls outside that circle. I don’t fully grasp the dynamics of AWS reinvestment or the razor-thin e-commerce margins at this scale.
2. Competitive Moat: Amazon has an impressive distribution network and AWS market share, but these advantages rest on continual technological investment and razor-competitive pricing. I look for pricing power that holds month in and month out—Amazon’s model forces it to reinvest, not raise prices.
3. Management Quality: Jeff Bezos and Andy Jassy are brilliant builders, but their focus on growth over free cash flow means minimal dividends or buybacks. Ownership-like capital allocation to shareholders is limited, and I prefer managers who think more about returns on capital than pure scale.
4. Financial Health & Consistency: A 6% ROE, 1.7 debt-to-equity, and a 2.2% ROIC tell me Amazon isn’t earning its cost of capital consistently. Earnings growth has been lumpy, and owner-earnings are negative once you strip out the massive capex—hardly the hallmark of a fortress balance sheet.
5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: The three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value, and there’s no margin of safety at today’s price. As I’ve said, “Price is what you pay; value is what you get.” Here, you’re paying dearly for uncertain free cash flow.
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: While e-commerce and cloud will grow, the business will require relentless capex and face stiff competition. Inconsistent profits and negative owner-earnings are red flags I can’t ignore.
7. Comparison to My Portfolio: I’d rather buy a marvelous business like Apple or Coca-Cola at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price. On these terms, Amazon doesn’t measure up.
Conclusion: Outside my circle, weak returns, negative owner-earnings, and no margin of safety lead me to pass.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 6.1%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.7; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 249.6% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 24.3%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (82.7%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric); Good book value CAGR: 11.1%

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (1.4%, 5y), Stage 2 (0.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
